Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: I need to write a DuckDB SQL query that filters out cases with more than six events and returns all events from cases that have six or fewer So the event log is in a table called event_log with columns case_id activity and timestamp

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: First I think I need to find out how many events each case_id has That means grouping by case_id and counting the rows Then I need to filter those groups where the count is greater than six

Name: Hypothesis Generation - PE
Text: So maybe first get the list of case_ids that have <=6 events then join that back with the original table to get all their events Right So a common approach is to use a subquery or a CTE to find the valid case_ids first

Name: Validation - PE
Text: What about cases where a case_id has exactly six events The HAVING clause uses <=6 so they are included Thats correct But what if there are multiple events per case and the count is accurate The GROUP BY case_id will correctly count each occurrence So thats fine

Name: Heuristic Reasoning - IND
Text: This might be more efficient but the subquery approach is more straightforward Both should work Which is better Well for the purpose of this task either approach is acceptable
